BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 7, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

IMPORTANT MEASURES ADOPTED

TOCQUEVILLE CONTEST CHANGED

SWIMMERS WIN FROM MARSTON'S

IMPORTANCE OF MEET GROWING

Year Divided into Two Semesters at
Faculty Meeting—Approaching Exams
to Be Held in March--Military
Training Next Year.

Medal, Formerly Awarded for Essay, to
Be Given for Excellence in Public
Speaking Preliminary Contest on March 3.

Hopkins Independent Team Victorious
Against Local Prep School—The
Two Rowlands and Capt.
Hoffman Star.

Difference Between Old Meets and New
Not Generally Realized—Need for
Whole-Hearted Support.

A recommendation to divide the
college year into two terms instead
of three, as at present, was favorably
acted upon at the Faculty meeting
Friday. This means that there will
be no more examinations at Christmas and Easter. Hereafter examinations will be held in February and
at the end of the year. It is proposed that informal marks be sent
out before the Christmas and Easter holidays to show the students
in what subjects they are back and
to give them a chance to catch up
during the holidays. This is one
of the principal advantages in the
new system. Another is that the
scholastic year will correspond to
the fiscal year. The change to two
terms is desirable, also, because
several subjects such as Polyton II,
Philosophy and Political Science
do not lend themselves to a division
into three parts.
Since, therefore, a mid-year examination is necessary for some of
the students, it is advantageous to
hold it for all.
For this year it vas further decided that the approaching spring
examinations shall be held in the
middle of March instead of just before Easter, as has been the custom.
The reason for this is that this year
Easter conies so late in the season
that there would only have been
about a month before the finals.
The Faculty passed a resolution
requesting the Board of Trustees
to establish a course of military
training at Hopkins, to be started
next year in accordance with the
provisions of the bill now before
Congress. The main features of
this bill are as follows:
(r) The President is authorized
to establish and maintain in civil
educational institutions a Reserve
Officers Training Corps, which shall
consist of a Senior Division organized at universities and colleges, and
a Junior Division organized„ at all
other public and private educational institutions. (Section 1.)
. (2) Where such units are established, the President shall detail an
officer of the regular army, active
or retired, and, if necessary, one or
more enlisted men, (Sections 6
and 7.)
(3) The Secretary of War shall
issue arms, uniforms, equipment,
etc., to those enrolled in these units.
(Section 8.)
(4) The Secretary of War is
authorized to establish and maintain instruction camps, for periods
of not more than six weeks, to pay

The Tocqueville !edal, which is
given to the University annually
by the Baron de Coubertin, and
which has hitherto been awarded as
an essay prize, will hereafter be a
prize for excellence in public speak-

By COACH JOSEPH T. ENGLAND.

New Hopkins Scholarships.

The trustees of the Johns Hopkins University have founded ten
new graduate scholarships, to be
given to students from the Southern and Western States. It was
thought that Hopkins ought to be
better known in that section of the,
country, and hence these scholarships were offered.
They have a value of $150 annually, but do not carry exemption
from laboratory fees. They will be
awarded on March T. Applications
for them should be made to the
registrar of the University.

To those who have followed Hopkins athletics during the last fifteen
years, nothing is more indicative of
the gradual advancement which is
taking- place than the honored
ranking that has been attained by
the annual Hopkins indoor meet in
the athletic world. There are many
persons in Baltimore who, either
as spectators or competitors, can
vividly recall the first Hopkins contest. Those of us who were privileged to compete will never forget the mad dashes of those days
around a circular track of 21 laps
in a small hall (the old Fifth Regiment Armory), full of frenzied
spectators. The floor was long
enough to permit a 30-yard dash,
but hurdle races, ma-yards and
..220-yards sprints were neither attempted nor dreamed of in the for
mer times. Similar limitations existed when the field events were
reached.
It :s not with any spirit of criticism that these matters of the past
are touched upon; rather of rever2nce. For the men who were administratively in charge of the
earlier meets, as well as the stalwart few who fought so valiantly
for the University in the actual
competition, unquestionably laid the
foundation and established all of the
customs and policies of the present
contests. The change from the old
to the new state of affairs took
place so easily and gradually that
very few Hopkins men look at the
matter in any other light than
"there has always been, and doubtless always will be, a big Hopkins
meet each year."
The earlier years have one cheerished tradition to hand down to the
present university man. When the
night of the indoor meet came
around, every then Hopkins' man
was in his place at the meet. Social
engagements and personal pleasures were forgotten. There was
organized cheering, lots .of it, and
the men on the team responded with
a rush. Finally, one year the relay team defeated Pennsylvania
admist a mighty roar, and the future of the indoor games was
established.
The contest this season will be
of a higher calibre than ever. Cornell, Princeton, Georgetown, Virginia, Washington andLee,Pennsylvania and other colleges are sending
large and representative squads of
men. In addition, one finds an ever
increasing list of entries pouring in
from the preparatory schools and

Wrestling as a minor sport has
been taken up by a number of Hopkins men during the past few weeks.
The mat in the east end of the locker room is being used by the grapplers, and many interesting little
matches can be seen there at 5
o'clock every Tuesday and Thursday evening. Most of the men are
novices, but they all seem to be interested in the sport and willing to
learn. Although Hopkins has never
been represented by a wrestling
team, there seems to be indications that the sport will be taken up
more in earnest.

Fell and Williams,Hopkins Students Who
Accompanied Ford to Europe, Back
at University—Say Criticisms
of Ford Are Unjust.

Tile two 11o1)kins s uclents, Bruce
Stockton Williams and Edgar T.
Fell, both graduates in the Political Sc_ence Department, who accompanied the Ford Peace Expedition, returned to the University
last week, after what they report
as the most interesting and instructive experience of their lives. Both
were equally enthusiastic over the
results of the journey. They said
that Ford's purpose has been entirely misunderstood in this country, and that the criticisms of Mr.
Ford and his Peace Expedition are
wholly unjust.
One of the most impressive things
about the whole journey, they said,
was that Henry Ford had taken
students from almost every prominent university in the country, not
with any idea that they would have
any immediate effect in stopping the
war, nor with the intention of having the students act as delegates to
any peace convention, but merely as
an education for the benefit of the
students themselves. Of course,
all these students are following international law and political science,
and, as this country's future diplomats and statesmen, they are expected eventually to use the experience and knowledge made possible
to them by the kindness of Ford
in the furtherance of the cause of
international peace.
According to Mr. Fell and Mr.
Williams, the forty students who
sailed with Ford on the Oscar II
number, they have staunchly upheld the honor of Hopkins in a
hitherto unexplored field, is attested
by the scores of the contests which
the Hopkins team has held with
the teams of other universities. It is
significant of the prowess which
Hopkins may eventually attain in
marksmanship that already the team
of Penn State Military College, an
institution which has had rifle practice for years, has been met and defeated.
In order to insure success in this
new field, however, it is vitally necessary that more men take part in
the weekly practices. Rumors are
current about the University concerning the establishment of a
course in military training; a petition has been signed by students
asking that such a course be introduced; and yet interest in the Rifle
Club, which is directly in line with
such a movement, is maintained by
only a few men! The Rifle Club
is a challenge to Hopkins, a direct
test of the permanence of Hopkins
enthusiasm. We cannot afford to
allow the result of that test to .be
tin favorable.

were most warmly received in all
the European cities visited. When
the party arrived at Christiania at
three in the morning, a delegation
of students from the University of
Christiania were present at the dock
to greet the party. The Norwegian students took the Americans
through their university, explained
their system of education, and exchanged opinions and ideas with
them. So it was everywhere. The
local colleges welcomed the American students, banqu,eted them, took
them sight-seeing, and did all in
their power to make their visit as
enjoyable and instructive as possible.
After trips through Norway and
Sweden, the party went to Denmark. Here the reception given the
students was most elaborate. Besides attending the meetings arranged in their honor by the Danish universities, the American students went to the conferences held
.twice daily by the entire peace party
for a discussion of the best methods
for accomplishing the purposes of
the expedition.
On leaving Copenhagen, the
peace party went through Germany
to Holland. On the trip through
the Teuton country, Mr. Williams
and Mr. Fell had a most interesting
experience. They were in a compartment of the train with several
other students when a lieutenant in
the German army entered and rode
with them for several hours. Finding that his fellow-travelers were
students and not newspaper reporters, the soldier talked more freely
than he would have otherwise, and
gave the students his ideas about
the war, told them stories of the
firing-line, and finally promised to
come to America and visit them
after Germany was victorious;
which result he prophesied would
come to pass.
In Holland, the party again received a cordial welcome. The
Peace Palace, which is kept tightly
locked all the year, except during
International Peace Conferences,
was opened for their benefit.
On January 1o, the body of students left Rotterdam for the United
States. The voyage home was as exciting as any portion of the whole
journey. On board were American
refugees from Germany, Belgians
,and English, and from them the
college men were able to get valuable information concerning the
financial, economical and military
condition of the warring nations.
The ship encountered stormy
weather for two weeks and then
ran out of coal, necessitating a stop
at Newfoundland before coming
down to New York. They arrived
in New York on January 29, eight
weeks to a day from the sailing of
the Oscar II.
The two Hopkins students said
that, although many college men
who had gone on the trip had been
forced to give up the idea of taking
their degrees this year, not one had
expressed the slightest regret .at
their action in leaving college to
go with Henry Ford.

Second Dance of Cotillon Club One of
Most Brilliant Ever Given at Hopkins-Over 200 Present.

The second- University Cotillon
held in McCoy Hall on Friday evening last proved a great success. The
hall was decorated with palms and
flowers, and the music was furnished by Louis Fisher's orchestra. The
main hall was crowded and many
couples found solace in dancing in
the surrounding corridors. At
o'clock supper was served, after
which dancing continued until
12.30.
The "stag-line," which at previous Cotillons has been greatly reduced, was large, and consequently
the dance ran more smoothly than
it had previously. A thing greatly
to be regretted was the absence of
the Faculty who are generally well
represented at the Cotillons.
After 12.30 o'clock, the traditional hour of breaking up, the- music
played four or five extra dances
which were greatly appreciated.
The attendance, when computed,
showed that over one hundred
couples, or two hundred people,
were present. This is a record
crowd for a Hopkins Cotillon, not
including, of course, the Senior
"Proms;" the next largest Cotillon
having been in the winter term of
1911, when one hundred and eighty
were present. The Senior prom
last year was the largest ball ever
given in McCoy Hall, six hundred
people being present.
The next Cotillion, which will
take place after the spring holidays,
has all the promise of being larger
than the one just past, as many men
save up their subscriptions rather
for the spring Cotillon than for
the winter one.

The annual Student Conference
for the men in the colleges of Ohio,
West Virginia and the Middle Atlantic States will be held this summer, as usual, at Eagles Mere
Park, Pa. There will be extensive
courses in various religious subjects,- among which will be the folloWing: Bible Study, Bible Leaders'
Training, The Study of the Spread
of Christianity, Evangelism and
Conference of Foreign Students.
All these subjects are of vital interest to the American college man.
Ad in addition to the courses outlined above, there will be personal
interviews between leaders and
delegates.
The purpose of all recreation will
be physical efficiency rather than
intercollegiate competition. The
usual matches will be played and
track and swimming meets will be
held, but an unusual effort will be
made to give every man at the conference an opportunity for sufficient
exercise every afternoon. Not only
are there good athletic fields and
tennis courts, but the lake affords
Splendid swimming and boating and
the mountain excels in walks and
climbs of rare beauty.

TIME OF ADAMS DEBATE CHANGED
Due to Conflict with McCoy Hall Concert,
Adams Society Asks Philodemic
for Change of Date Duncan
Replaces Steinbach.

Another recent development in
connection with this debate is the
resignation of Alexander A. Steinbach from the team, due to the
pressure of collegiate work. His
place has been filled by Robert R.
Duncan, '18.
The subject of the debate is "Resolved, That the President of the
United States should be elected to
a single term of six years." The
Adams has the negative of the question. The members of the team are
already at work gathering material
and planning their speeches.
Besides Duncan, the Adams team
consists of Thomas J. Tingley and
Reuben' Oppenheimer. Each of
these men will make a first speech
of ten minutes and a rebuttal of
five. This arrangement, although
not the one originally advocated by
the Adams committee, was earnestly
supported by the Philodemic, and is
entirely satisfactory to the Hopkins
men. The first speaker for the
Adams will be Duncan; Oppenheimer will come next, and Tingley will conclude the debate.

Owing to a conflict with the annual McCoy Hall concert of the
Musical Clubs, the date of debate
between the Adams Literary Society of this University and the Philodemic Society of Georgetown has
again been changed.
The former date was Friday,
February 25. The debate committee of the Adams, in making this

that the Musical Clubs had already
chosen that night for their McCoy
Hall concert, and consequently
agreed when this date was suggested by the Philodemic. Realizing,
however, that it would be unadvis:
able to hold two Hopkins functions
on the same night, and that the
members of the Adams team themselves wished to attend the Musical

a letter to Georgetown, asking that

IMPORTANCE OF MEET GROWING

Year Divided into Two Semesters at
Faculty Meeting—Approaching Exams
to Be Held in March--Military
Training Next Year.

Medal, Formerly Awarded for Essay, to
Be Given for Excellence in Public
Speaking Preliminary Contest on March 3.

Hopkins Independent Team Victorious
Against Local Prep School—The
Two Rowlands and Capt.
Hoffman Star.

Difference Between Old Meets and New
Not Generally Realized—Need for
Whole-Hearted Support.

A recommendation to divide the
college year into two terms instead
of three, as at present, was favorably
acted upon at the Faculty meeting
Friday. This means that there will
be no more examinations at Christmas and Easter. Hereafter examinations will be held in February and
at the end of the year. It is proposed that informal marks be sent
out before the Christmas and Easter holidays to show the students
in what subjects they are back and
to give them a chance to catch up
during the holidays. This is one
of the principal advantages in the
new system. Another is that the
scholastic year will correspond to
the fiscal year. The change to two
terms is desirable, also, because
several subjects such as Polyton II,
Philosophy and Political Science
do not lend themselves to a division
into three parts.
Since, therefore, a mid-year examination is necessary for some of
the students, it is advantageous to
hold it for all.
For this year it vas further decided that the approaching spring
examinations shall be held in the
middle of March instead of just before Easter, as has been the custom.
The reason for this is that this year
Easter conies so late in the season
that there would only have been
about a month before the finals.
The Faculty passed a resolution
requesting the Board of Trustees
to establish a course of military
training at Hopkins, to be started
next year in accordance with the
provisions of the bill now before
Congress. The main features of
this bill are as follows:
(r) The President is authorized
to establish and maintain in civil
educational institutions a Reserve
Officers Training Corps, which shall
consist of a Senior Division organized at universities and colleges, and
a Junior Division organized„ at all
other public and private educational institutions. (Section 1.)
. (2) Where such units are established, the President shall detail an
officer of the regular army, active
or retired, and, if necessary, one or
more enlisted men, (Sections 6
and 7.)
(3) The Secretary of War shall
issue arms, uniforms, equipment,
etc., to those enrolled in these units.
(Section 8.)
(4) The Secretary of War is
authorized to establish and maintain instruction camps, for periods
of not more than six weeks, to pay

The Tocqueville !edal, which is
given to the University annually
by the Baron de Coubertin, and
which has hitherto been awarded as
an essay prize, will hereafter be a
prize for excellence in public speak-

New Hopkins Scholarships.

new graduate scholarships, to be
given to students from the Southern and Western States. It was
thought that Hopkins ought to be
better known in that section of the,
country, and hence these scholarships were offered.

from laboratory fees. They will be
awarded on March T. Applications
for them should be made to the

To those who have followed Hopkins athletics during the last fifteen
years, nothing is more indicative of
the gradual advancement which is
taking- place than the honored
ranking that has been attained by
the annual Hopkins indoor meet in
the athletic world. There are many
persons in Baltimore who, either
as spectators or competitors, can
vividly recall the first Hopkins contest. Those of us who were privileged to compete will never forget the mad dashes of those days
around a circular track of 21 laps
in a small hall (the old Fifth Regiment Armory), full of frenzied
spectators. The floor was long
enough to permit a 30-yard dash,
but hurdle races, ma-yards and
..220-yards sprints were neither attempted nor dreamed of in the for
mer times. Similar limitations existed when the field events were
reached.
It :s not with any spirit of criticism that these matters of the past
are touched upon; rather of rever2nce. For the men who were administratively in charge of the
earlier meets, as well as the stalwart few who fought so valiantly
for the University in the actual
competition, unquestionably laid the
foundation and established all of the
customs and policies of the present
contests. The change from the old
to the new state of affairs took
place so easily and gradually that
very few Hopkins men look at the
matter in any other light than
"there has always been, and doubtless always will be, a big Hopkins
meet each year."
The earlier years have one cheerished tradition to hand down to the
present university man. When the
night of the indoor meet came
around, every then Hopkins' man
was in his place at the meet. Social
engagements and personal pleasures were forgotten. There was
organized cheering, lots .of it, and
the men on the team responded with
a rush. Finally, one year the relay team defeated Pennsylvania
admist a mighty roar, and the future of the indoor games was
established.
The contest this season will be
of a higher calibre than ever. Cornell, Princeton, Georgetown, Virginia, Washington andLee,Pennsylvania and other colleges are sending
large and representative squads of
men. In addition, one finds an ever
increasing list of entries pouring in
from the preparatory schools and

Wrestling as a minor sport has
been taken up by a number of Hopkins men during the past few weeks.
The mat in the east end of the locker room is being used by the grapplers, and many interesting little
matches can be seen there at 5
o'clock every Tuesday and Thursday evening. Most of the men are
novices, but they all seem to be interested in the sport and willing to
learn. Although Hopkins has never
been represented by a wrestling
team, there seems to be indications that the sport will be taken up
more in earnest.

PEACE PARTY MEMBERS RETURN
Fell and Williams,Hopkins Students Who
Accompanied Ford to Europe, Back
at University—Say Criticisms
of Ford Are Unjust.

Tile two 11o1)kins s uclents, Bruce
Stockton Williams and Edgar T.
Fell, both graduates in the Political Sc_ence Department, who accompanied the Ford Peace Expedition, returned to the University
last week, after what they report
as the most interesting and instructive experience of their lives. Both
were equally enthusiastic over the
results of the journey. They said
that Ford's purpose has been entirely misunderstood in this country, and that the criticisms of Mr.
Ford and his Peace Expedition are
wholly unjust.
One of the most impressive things
about the whole journey, they said,
was that Henry Ford had taken
students from almost every prominent university in the country, not
with any idea that they would have
any immediate effect in stopping the
war, nor with the intention of having the students act as delegates to
any peace convention, but merely as
an education for the benefit of the
students themselves. Of course,
all these students are following international law and political science,
and, as this country's future diplomats and statesmen, they are expected eventually to use the experience and knowledge made possible
to them by the kindness of Ford
in the furtherance of the cause of
international peace.
According to Mr. Fell and Mr.
Williams, the forty students who
sailed with Ford on the Oscar II
number, they have staunchly upheld the honor of Hopkins in a
hitherto unexplored field, is attested
by the scores of the contests which
the Hopkins team has held with
the teams of other universities. It is
significant of the prowess which
Hopkins may eventually attain in
marksmanship that already the team
of Penn State Military College, an
institution which has had rifle practice for years, has been met and defeated.
In order to insure success in this
new field, however, it is vitally necessary that more men take part in
the weekly practices. Rumors are
current about the University concerning the establishment of a
course in military training; a petition has been signed by students
asking that such a course be introduced; and yet interest in the Rifle
Club, which is directly in line with
such a movement, is maintained by
only a few men! The Rifle Club
is a challenge to Hopkins, a direct
test of the permanence of Hopkins
enthusiasm. We cannot afford to
allow the result of that test to .be
tin favorable.

were most warmly received in all
the European cities visited. When
the party arrived at Christiania at
three in the morning, a delegation
of students from the University of
Christiania were present at the dock
to greet the party. The Norwegian students took the Americans
through their university, explained
their system of education, and exchanged opinions and ideas with
them. So it was everywhere. The
local colleges welcomed the American students, banqu,eted them, took
them sight-seeing, and did all in
their power to make their visit as
enjoyable and instructive as possible.
After trips through Norway and
Sweden, the party went to Denmark. Here the reception given the
students was most elaborate. Besides attending the meetings arranged in their honor by the Danish universities, the American students went to the conferences held
.twice daily by the entire peace party
for a discussion of the best methods
for accomplishing the purposes of
the expedition.
On leaving Copenhagen, the
peace party went through Germany
to Holland. On the trip through
the Teuton country, Mr. Williams
and Mr. Fell had a most interesting
experience. They were in a compartment of the train with several
other students when a lieutenant in
the German army entered and rode
with them for several hours. Finding that his fellow-travelers were
students and not newspaper reporters, the soldier talked more freely
than he would have otherwise, and
gave the students his ideas about
the war, told them stories of the
firing-line, and finally promised to
come to America and visit them
after Germany was victorious;
which result he prophesied would
come to pass.
In Holland, the party again received a cordial welcome. The
Peace Palace, which is kept tightly
locked all the year, except during
International Peace Conferences,
was opened for their benefit.
On January 1o, the body of students left Rotterdam for the United
States. The voyage home was as exciting as any portion of the whole
journey. On board were American
refugees from Germany, Belgians
,and English, and from them the
college men were able to get valuable information concerning the
financial, economical and military
condition of the warring nations.
The ship encountered stormy
weather for two weeks and then
ran out of coal, necessitating a stop
at Newfoundland before coming
down to New York. They arrived
in New York on January 29, eight
weeks to a day from the sailing of
the Oscar II.
The two Hopkins students said
that, although many college men
who had gone on the trip had been
forced to give up the idea of taking
their degrees this year, not one had
expressed the slightest regret .at
their action in leaving college to
go with Henry Ford.

HELD AGAIN AT EAGLES MERE

Second Dance of Cotillon Club One of
Most Brilliant Ever Given at Hopkins-Over 200 Present.

The second- University Cotillon
held in McCoy Hall on Friday evening last proved a great success. The
hall was decorated with palms and
flowers, and the music was furnished by Louis Fisher's orchestra. The
main hall was crowded and many
couples found solace in dancing in
the surrounding corridors. At
o'clock supper was served, after
which dancing continued until
12.30.
The "stag-line," which at previous Cotillons has been greatly reduced, was large, and consequently
the dance ran more smoothly than
it had previously. A thing greatly
to be regretted was the absence of
the Faculty who are generally well
represented at the Cotillons.
After 12.30 o'clock, the traditional hour of breaking up, the- music
played four or five extra dances
which were greatly appreciated.
The attendance, when computed,
showed that over one hundred
couples, or two hundred people,
were present. This is a record
crowd for a Hopkins Cotillon, not
including, of course, the Senior
"Proms;" the next largest Cotillon
having been in the winter term of
1911, when one hundred and eighty
were present. The Senior prom
last year was the largest ball ever
given in McCoy Hall, six hundred
people being present.
The next Cotillion, which will
take place after the spring holidays,
has all the promise of being larger
than the one just past, as many men
save up their subscriptions rather
for the spring Cotillon than for
the winter one.

The annual Student Conference
for the men in the colleges of Ohio,
West Virginia and the Middle Atlantic States will be held this summer, as usual, at Eagles Mere
Park, Pa. There will be extensive
courses in various religious subjects,- among which will be the folloWing: Bible Study, Bible Leaders'
Training, The Study of the Spread
of Christianity, Evangelism and
Conference of Foreign Students.
All these subjects are of vital interest to the American college man.
Ad in addition to the courses outlined above, there will be personal
interviews between leaders and
delegates.
The purpose of all recreation will
be physical efficiency rather than
intercollegiate competition. The
usual matches will be played and
track and swimming meets will be
held, but an unusual effort will be
made to give every man at the conference an opportunity for sufficient
exercise every afternoon. Not only
are there good athletic fields and
tennis courts, but the lake affords
Splendid swimming and boating and
the mountain excels in walks and
climbs of rare beauty.

Another recent development in
connection with this debate is the
resignation of Alexander A. Steinbach from the team, due to the
pressure of collegiate work. His
place has been filled by Robert R.
Duncan, '18.
The subject of the debate is "Resolved, That the President of the
United States should be elected to
a single term of six years." The
Adams has the negative of the question. The members of the team are
already at work gathering material
and planning their speeches.
Besides Duncan, the Adams team
consists of Thomas J. Tingley and
Reuben' Oppenheimer. Each of
these men will make a first speech
of ten minutes and a rebuttal of
five. This arrangement, although
not the one originally advocated by
the Adams committee, was earnestly
supported by the Philodemic, and is
entirely satisfactory to the Hopkins
men. The first speaker for the
Adams will be Duncan; Oppenheimer will come next, and Tingley will conclude the debate.

between the Adams Literary Society of this University and the Philodemic Society of Georgetown has
